title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: An involuntary spasm of the diaphragm

multiple-choice.question: What is the diaphragm?

options.label: A
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the skin

options.label: B
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the heart

options.label: D
options.text: A sheet of muscle under the stomach

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the vagus nerve in hiccup relief?

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate some of the body's most important functions

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to stimulate the vagus nerve and relieve hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: By swallowing a teaspoon of sugar

options.label: C
options.text: By drinking a glass of water

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of holding your breath on hiccup relief?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the level of oxygen in the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on hiccup relief

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and relieve hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: By drinking a glass of water

options.label: C
options.text: By breathing into a paper bag

options.label: A
options.text: To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet

options.label: B
options.text: To provide information on hiccup relief

options.label: C
options.text: To provide information on breathing techniques

options.label: D
options.text: To provide information on the human body

multiple-choice.question: How can people contribute to the World's Most Asked Questions series?

options.label: A
options.text: By filling out the SciShow Survey

options.label: B
options.text: By answering questions on Facebook or Twitter

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: To weigh options and choose the best design.

options.label: B
options.text: Weighing options and choosing the best design.

options.label: D
options.text: Weighing options and choosing the best design.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Do Not Enter" sign in the engineer's room?

options.label: B
options.text: To create a secluded and quiet space.

title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of researchers when a new virus emerges?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop a cure for the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: To collect data about who's been infected.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a vaccine for the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the genetic material of the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is PCR (polymerase chain reaction) testing used to diagnose?

options.label: A
options.text: If someone has been infected with a virus in the past.

options.label: B
options.text: If someone is currently infected with a virus.

options.label: C
options.text: If someone has developed immunity to a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: If someone has a specific genetic condition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing the genetic material of a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a vaccine for the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a cure for the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify regions that are unique to that specific virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between PCR and immunoassays?

options.label: A
options.text: PCR targets the virus's genetic material, while immunoassays target the immune system's memory of the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: PCR is used to diagnose current infections, while immunoassays are used to diagnose past infections.

options.label: C
options.text: PCR is used to detect IgG antibodies, while immunoassays are used to detect IgM antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: PCR is used to detect the presence of a virus, while immunoassays are used to detect the absence of a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of reverse transcription in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To make a strand of complementary DNA from the viral RNA.

options.label: B
options.text: To make a strand of complementary RNA from the viral DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: To make a strand of viral RNA from the complementary DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: To make a strand of viral DNA from the complementary RNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of enzymes in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To amplify genetic information to large enough quantities.

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the presence of a virus.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a vaccine for the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using probes marked with fluorescent dye in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of a virus.

options.label: B
options.text: To amplify genetic information to large enough quantities.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a vaccine for the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between IgM and IgG antibodies?

options.label: A
options.text: IgM antibodies are produced in response to a new infection, while IgG antibodies are produced in response to a past infection.

options.label: B
options.text: IgM antibodies are produced in response to a past infection, while IgG antibodies are produced in response to a new infection.

options.label: C
options.text: IgM antibodies are produced in response to a virus, while IgG antibodies are produced in response to a bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: IgM antibodies are produced in response to a bacteria, while IgG antibodies are produced in response to a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of immunoassays?

options.label: C
options.text: To detect the presence of a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect the absence of a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential use of blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a vaccine for the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the behavior of the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: To treat individuals who are currently fighting the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect the presence of the virus.

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the recent rise in outbreaks of viruses like Ebola and SARS?

options.label: A
options.text: The viruses are becoming more aggressive.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans and animals are creeping into bats' territory, especially in the tropics.

options.label: C
options.text: The viruses are mutating and becoming more resistant to treatment.

options.label: D
options.text: The bats are becoming more social and spreading the viruses more easily.

multiple-choice.question: Which animal is likely to carry more human-killing diseases than any other animal?
Why do most infected bats not die from the viruses they carry?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a strong immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they live in isolation and don't come into contact with other bats.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can survive the viruses due to their ability to fly and produce specialized cells that keep viral invaders in check.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not susceptible to the viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why bats are resilient to infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a strong immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they live in isolation and don't come into contact with other bats.

options.label: C
options.text: Because flight may have leveled-up their in-flight DNA damage repair kits and other defenses.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not susceptible to the viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why viruses that infect bats can survive the bats themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bats have a strong immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the viruses are too aggressive for the bats to handle.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the viruses have evolved to tolerate the heat generated by the bats' flight.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the bats are not susceptible to the viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What should humans do to minimize the risk of disease transmission from bats?

options.label: A
options.text: We should try to control the spread of diseases carried by bats.

options.label: B
options.text: We should leave bats alone and try to control the spread of diseases carried by a different kind of flying mammal.

options.label: C
options.text: We should try to eradicate bats from the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: We should try to make bats more susceptible to disease.

title: Why is my leg asleep?

options.label: A

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason you can feel something when you touch it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the muscles in your body.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of little things called nerves that are all over your body.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the blood vessels in your body.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the skin on your body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "pins and needles" feeling?

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of a light breeze on your skin.

options.label: C
options.text: A feeling of tiny little pokes or prickles, even though nothing is really touching you.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They start to feel tired and can't move.

options.text: To pump blood through little tubes called blood vessels.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important that the blood moves through all the parts of your body?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it gives you energy so you can work properly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps you digest food.

options.label: A
options.text: They start working perfectly and can feel everything normally.

options.label: B
options.text: They get a little confused and start telling your brain that you're feeling tiny little pokes, even though nothing is really touching you.

options.label: C
options.text: They start to hurt and can't feel anything at all.

options.label: D
options.text: They start to feel tired and can't move.

title: Plurals -s -es | Learn to Spell

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the machine shown in the laboratory?
What is the function of the Pluralator?

options.label: C
options.text: To make more than one of a word

options.label: D
options.text: To change the meaning of a word

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the "t" or "s" that is added to a word to show there is more than one?
What is the sound that is made by the plural "s"?
When do you use the plural "es"?

options.label: A
options.text: After a word that ends in "s"

options.label: B
options.text: After a word that ends in "h"

options.label: C
options.text: After a word that has a hissing sound

options.label: D
options.text: After a word that ends in "e"

multiple-choice.question: What are some examples of words that end in "s" and require the plural "es"?
What is the term for the plural that is used to show there is more than one of a word.
What happens when the Pluralator gets out of control?

options.label: C
options.text: It starts making more than one of a word at a time

options.label: D
options.text: It starts making no words at all

multiple-choice.question: How does the student in the laboratory react to the Pluralator getting out of control?

options.label: A
options.text: They are excited and want to see more

options.label: B
options.text: They are scared and want to run away

options.label: C
options.text: They are bored and want to take a nap

options.label: D
options.text: They are clever and try to stop it

multiple-choice.question: What is the student's reaction to being called an "excellent student"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are embarrassed and want to hide

options.label: B
options.text: They are proud and want to show off

options.label: C
options.text: They are bored and want to leave

options.label: D
options.text: They are clever and want to learn more

title: Closed and open syllables | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a vowel is in an open syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a vowel is in a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable?
Which of the following words is an example of an open syllable?
What is the rule for determining whether a syllable is open or closed?

options.label: A
options.text: If the vowel is at the beginning of the word, it is open.

options.label: B
options.text: If the vowel makes a short sound, it is closed.

options.label: C
options.text: If the vowel says its letter name, it is open.

options.label: D
options.text: If the vowel is at the end of the word, it is closed.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words has an open syllable?
Which of the following words has a closed syllable?
What is the opposite of an open syllable?
Which of the following words is an example of a word with an open syllable?
Which of the following words is an example of a word with a closed syllable?

title: The L-iminator! | The double L spelling rule

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two words join together to make a new word?

options.label: B
options.text: They become one word with a hyphen.

options.label: C
options.text: They become one word with a space.

options.label: D
options.text: They become one word with one of the letters eliminated.

options.text: A word that has a prefix and a suffix.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A word that has a root and a base.

options.label: D
options.text: A word that has a homophone and a homograph.

options.text: A new word with one letter.

options.label: C
options.text: A new word with no letters.

options.label: D
options.text: A new word with one of the letters eliminated.

title: Human, capital & natural resources for kids | Types of resources

multiple-choice.question: What is a resource?

options.label: A
options.text: Something that people use to meet their needs.

options.label: B
options.text: Something that people use to meet their wants.

options.label: C
options.text: Something that people use to meet their desires.

options.label: D
options.text: Something that people use to meet their goals.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main types of resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and natural resources.

options.label: B
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and material resources.

options.label: C
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and financial resources.

options.label: D
options.text: Human resources, capital resources, and technological resources.

multiple-choice.question: What are human resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: B
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Things that are used to make goods.

multiple-choice.question: What are capital resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: B
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Things that are used to make goods.

multiple-choice.question: What are natural resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Goods that are made and used to provide a service.

options.label: B
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people.

options.label: D
options.text: Things that are used to make goods.

multiple-choice.question: What is a service?

options.label: A
options.text: Something that someone does for you.

options.label: B
options.text: Something that someone does for themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: Something that someone does for others.

options.label: D
options.text: Something that someone does for a company.

multiple-choice.question: What are goods?

options.label: A
options.text: Things that you use, eat, or drink.

options.label: B
options.text: Things that you don't use, eat, or drink.

options.label: C
options.text: Things that you make, eat, or drink.

options.label: D
options.text: Things that you don't make, eat, or drink.

multiple-choice.question: What are chefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Human resources that make goods for people to eat.

options.label: B
options.text: Human resources that make goods for people to drink.

options.label: C
options.text: Human resources that make goods for people to use.

options.label: D
options.text: Human resources that make goods for people to buy.

multiple-choice.question: What are stoves, pots, and cooking utensils?

options.label: A
options.text: Capital resources that are used to make goods.

options.label: B
options.text: Capital resources that are used to provide a service.

options.label: C
options.text: Capital resources that are used to make food.

options.label: D
options.text: Capital resources that are used to make drinks.

multiple-choice.question: How do families use different types of resources?

options.label: A
options.text: They use human resources to make goods.

options.label: B
options.text: They use capital resources to make goods.

options.label: C
options.text: They use natural resources to make goods.

options.label: D
options.text: They use all types of resources to meet their needs.
